body_html:
You need to enable soft placement when creating the session. It's a configuration o parameter in tf.ConfigProto.
…
On Fri, Dec 15, 2017, 8:15 AM Andrew Matteson ***@***.***> wrote: I can't really quite understand the implications of this. Does this prevent LSTMs from being placed on the GPU? I'm trying to do multi-GPU which requires explicit assignment of GPU devices, and suddenly when I start explicitly designing devices I start hitting this assert op that's apparently not supported on GPU. But I don't understand how it was running fine on a single GPU in the first place? What I do know is that I commented out the assert, explicitly defined GPU devices and multi-GPU code is working very well now. But I am left with a lot of confusion as well. — You are receiving this because you were mentioned. Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub <#2594 (comment)>, or mute the thread <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/ABtim0vOVI2fEUTYAYZUX9mjuW3gaG8iks5tAps3gaJpZM4Iq0IV> .
body_text:
You need to enable soft placement when creating the session.  It's a
configuration o parameter in tf.ConfigProto.
…
On Fri, Dec 15, 2017, 8:15 AM Andrew Matteson ***@***.***> wrote:
 I can't really quite understand the implications of this. Does this
 prevent LSTMs from being placed on the GPU?

 I'm trying to do multi-GPU which requires explicit assignment of GPU
 devices, and suddenly when I start explicitly designing devices I start
 hitting this assert op that's apparently not supported on GPU. But I don't
 understand how it was running fine on a single GPU in the first place?

 What I do know is that I commented out the assert, explicitly defined GPU
 devices and multi-GPU code is working very well now. But I am left with a
 lot of confusion as well.

 —

body:
You need to enable soft placement when creating the session.  It's a
configuration o parameter in tf.ConfigProto.

On Fri, Dec 15, 2017, 8:15 AM Andrew Matteson <notifications@github.com>
wrote:

> I can't really quite understand the implications of this. Does this
> prevent LSTMs from being placed on the GPU?
>
> I'm trying to do multi-GPU which requires explicit assignment of GPU
> devices, and suddenly when I start explicitly designing devices I start
> hitting this assert op that's apparently not supported on GPU. But I don't
> understand how it was running fine on a single GPU in the first place?
>
> What I do know is that I commented out the assert, explicitly defined GPU
> devices and multi-GPU code is working very well now. But I am left with a
> lot of confusion as well.
>
> —
